title: Sumer: The Mythological Kings and the First Dynasty of Kish
header: Sumer: The Mythological Kings and the First Dynasty of Kish
common:
Writing and Myths

The creation of writing systems not only allowed the description of facts but also the creation of myths (History Tracers, , A escrita). On this page, we list the kings considered mythological in the Weld-Blundell prism (History with Cy, ). Why mythological kings? We consider these kings mythological for the following reasons:

• No evidence other than the prism has been found to prove the existence of these kings (History with Cy, ).
  • Reign periods that are impossible for human beings (Ashmolean Museum Oxford)
  • The presence of a sentence written using a figure of speech (Grindon, Leopold H., ): "Then the flood swept over. After the flood had swept over, and the kingship had descended from heaven" (Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, ).
Due to the frequent confusion with the literal interpretation of the Mesopotamian flood, we wrote a serie of four texts to help readers to undertstand what ancient authors were describing:

• (Texts with Sciences (Part I)): we study the concepts of "world" and "sky" in Mesopotamian cultures and how the lack of understanding of the surrounding environment may have led to the idea of an extraordinarily long lifespan, incompatible with human nature.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Part II)): we explore the water cycle and the law of conservation of mass. With this, we discussed how the concept of "world" in Mesopotamia differs from our own.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Part III)): we examined the epics of *Gilgamesh* and *Atrahasis*, as well as the Sumerian deluge narratives. Within them, we identified a recurring narrative pattern: a few people and animals are saved in a boat, described in various shapes (cubic or circular), following a divine punishment. From this, we established the probable periods in which these deluges occurred and compared them with data from other regions, concluding that there were no global floods.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Conclusion)): we concluded our study with an analysis of two different papers that mapped floods across the world at various times, providing context for the conditions under which Mediterranean authors wrote their texts.

maps.text: Part of map of Asia highlighting the region from Mesopotamia to the Zagros Mountains in Iran, representing the areas occupied by the ancient Sumerians (Kessler, P. L., ). The area is marked approximately to provide the reader with a clearer visualization

families.name: Kings of Eridu
history: Kings that [supposed] lived in Eridu (Unesco - World Heritage Convention, ) after "descended from heaven" (Black, J.A. et. all, ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, ).

people.name: Alulim
history: He ruled for 28800 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 3, 4 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

people.name: Alaljar
history: He ruled for 36000 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 5, 6 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

families.name: Kings of Bad-tibira
history: Kings that [supposed] lived in Bad-tibira after the fall of Eridu (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 8, 9 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

people.name: Enmenluana
history: He ruled for 43200 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 11, 12 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

people.name: Enmengalana
history: He ruled for 28800 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 13, 14 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

people.name: Dumuzid
history: A god also known by "shepherd" (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 15 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09 ; Dijk-Coombes, Renate Marian van., ).
He ruled for 36000 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 13, 14 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

marriages.name: Inanna
history: Cited by Renate Marian van Dijk-Coombes (Dijk-Coombes, Renate Marian van., ).

families.name: King of Larag
history: King that [supposed] lived in Larag after the fall of Bad-tibira (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 18, 19 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

people.name: Ensipadzidana
history: He ruled for 28800 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 20, 21 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

families.name: King of Zimbir (Sippar)
history: King that [supposed] lived in Zimbir (Sippar) after the fall of Larag (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 24, 26 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

people.name: Enmendurana
history: He ruled for 21000 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 26, 27 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

families.name: King of Curuppag
history: King that [supposed] lived in Curuppag after the fall of Zimbir (Sippar) (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 30, 31 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

people.name: Ubara-Tutu
history: He ruled for 18600 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 32, 33 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ; History with Cy, , 05:09).

families.name: Kings of Kish (Part I)
history: This city in the list of kings begins to include historically recognized figures, such as Enmebagaresi (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, , Kish ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, , Enmebaragesi ; History with Cy, , 06:32). However, there are still records of reigns with durations impossible for human beings, as discussed in the introduction.

people.name: Jucur
history: He ruled for 1200 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 43 - 45 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Kullassina-bel
history: He ruled for 960/900 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 46 - 47 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Nanjiclicma
history: He ruled for 960 (?) years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 48 - 49 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: En-tarah-ana
history: He ruled for (?) 420 years ...., 3 months, and 3 1/2 days (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 50 - 51 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).
We can't help but highlight the "precision" of the duration attributed to this king's reign.

people.name: Babum
history: He ruled for (?) 300 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 52 - 53 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Puannum
history: He ruled for (?) 840/240 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 54 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Kalibum
history: He ruled for (?) 960/900 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 55 - 56 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Kalumum
history: He ruled for (?) 840/900 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 57 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Zuqaqip
history: He ruled for (?) 900/600 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 58 - 59 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

families.name: Kings of Kish (Part II)
history: Before Atab/Aba, the translation of the Sumerian king list informs us: "the 10th and 11th rulers of the dynasty preceded the 8th and 9th" (Black, J.A. et. all, ). This is the first instance in the list where we observe a relationship between fathers and sons, suggesting the establishment of a dynasty.

people.name: Atab/Aba
history: He ruled for (?) 600 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 58 - 59 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

children.name: Macda
history: According to the list of kings (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 61 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Macda
history: He ruled for 840/720 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 61 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

children.name: Arwium
history: According to the list of kings (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 62 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Arwium
history: He ruled for 720 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 62 - 63 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

families.name: Kings of Kish (Part III)
history: In this section, we explore the mythological figure Etana, the shepherd, who is described as: "who ascended to heaven and consolidated all the foreign countries" (Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Etana
history: He ruled 1,500 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 64 - 67 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

In addition to being mentioned in the List of Kings, Etana is also the central figure in an epic that bears his name. Although the epic has survived only in fragments, it is accessible through the Electronic Babylonian Library and World History Encyclopedia (Etana, Eletronic Babylonian Library ; Mark, J. J, , World History Encyclopedia).

children.name: Balih
history: According to the List of Kings (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 69 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Balih
history: He ruled for 400 (410) years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 70 - 71 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

families.name: Kings of Kish (Part IV)
history: In this fourth part we have the En-me-nuna's family (Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: En-me-nuna
history: He ruled for 660 (621) years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 64 - 67 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

children.name: Melem-Kic
history: According to the List of Kings (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 72 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

children.name: Barsal-nuna
history: According to the List of Kings (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 74 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

This relationship is considered hypothetical because, in the List of Kings where Barsal-nuna is mentioned, there is an earlier reference stating: 1560 are the years of the dynasty of En-me-nuna (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 73A ; Black, J.A. et. all, ). However, the combined reigns of En-me-nuna and his supposed brother exceed this period, suggesting a possible error or the existence of a homonym.

people.name: Melem-Kic
history: He ruled for 900 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 72 - 73 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Barsal-nuna
history: He ruled for 1200 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 74 - 75 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

children.name: Zamug
history: According to the List of Kings (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 76 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Zamug
history: He ruled for 140 year (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 76 - 77 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

children.name: Tizqar
history: According to the List of Kings (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 78 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Tizqar
history: He ruled for 305 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 78 - 79 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

families.name: Kings of Kish (Part V)
history: This is the last group of kings on this page for which there is no physical evidence of their existence, aside from ancient texts. In other words, this is the final section covering the mythological figures of the First Dynasty of Kish.

Are texts considered primary sources? This is a question that requires further exploration. Documents that have survived to the present day are considered primary sources and can help confirm the existence of historical figures. However, the further back we go in time, the more we encounter a blend of history and belief within these texts. We understand that a person truly existed when, in addition to textual references — often recorded centuries or even millennia after the person’s supposed lifetime — there is also physical evidence, such as artifacts, to support those mentions.
Can oral tradition preserve names for centuries? This is a commonly raised argument, which leads to the following reflection:

Reflection 4: The Limits of Oral Tradition

Is oral tradition enough to confirm the historical existence of a person? Or is it more of a collective belief, not necessarily supported by concrete evidence?
Would you accept oral traditions that contradict your own beliefs?

people.name: Ilku
history: He ruled for 900 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 80 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Iltasadum
history: He ruled for 1200 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 81 - 82 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

families.name: Kings of Kish (Part VI)
history: In concluding the analysis of the early kings of Kish, we encounter the dynasty of Enmebaragesi, the first king whose existence has been confirmed by archaeological evidence (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, , Kish ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, , Enmebaragesi ; History with Cy, , 06:32).

people.name: Enmebaragesi
history: According to the Sumerian King List, Enmebaragesi ruled for 900 years and conquered the region of Elam (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 83 - 86 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ). His existence has been confirmed through excavations that uncovered fragments of a contemporary vase bearing the inscription: "me-bara2-si lugal kisz" (RIME 1.07.22.02, ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, , Enmebaragesi ; Edzard, D. O., )
Figure 4: Representation of the vase featuring the inscription that confirms the king's existence.

children.name: Aga
history: According to the List of Kings (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 87 - 88 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).

people.name: Aga
history: Aga, son of Enmebaragesi, is also listed in the Sumerian King List. He reportedly ruled for 625 years (Black, J.A. et. all, , ln. 89 ; Black, J.A. et. all, ). Aga is also mentioned in the Sumerian poem Gilgamesh and Aga, which recounts a meeting between Aga and Gilgamesh, the king of Uruk (Black, J.A. et. all, ; Black, J.A. et. all, ).
This literary reference leads us to the following reflection:

?
Floods in the Ancient Middle East

The Epic of Gilgamesh describes a great flood, and considering that Gilgamesh lived during the same period as Aga, it is possible that this flood does not correspond to the one mentioned earlier in the Sumerian King List. This is because Aga began his reign approximately 23,885 years after the flood recorded at the beginning of the list (Gilgamesh epic ; Mark, J. J., , Gilgamesh). However, if we consider only the reigns of Enmebaragesi—historically the first verified king—and his son, the time gap between these events reduces significantly.
How many floods might have occurred in the ancient Mediterranean world?

Samuel Noah Kramer noted that floods in the Middle East were not uncommon. For example, in , the Tigris River "submerged the low-lying plain for hundreds of miles" (Kramer, Samuel Noah, ). Kramer concluded that the flood described in ancient texts likely had its origins in a real catastrophic event, though it was not a universal event.

Reflection 5: The Flood

In addition to the previously mentioned challenge of understanding how ancient Middle Eastern people viewed their world, there is another potential source of misunderstanding. In some places, it is still taught that civilization had only one cradle. However, modern understanding shows us that there were at least six distinct cradles of civilization: China, India, Mesopotamia, Egypt, Mesoamerica, and Peru (Peru: Cradle of Civilization. Museo Larco).
Did you know that there were six different cradles of civilization?

exercise_v2.question: Has the historical existence of all the kings listed in the Sumerian King List been proven?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: With the exception of the last two kings, the lack of information about the other kings suggest they are mythological figures.

exercise_v2.question: Did the floods that occurred in the Mediterranean region flood the entire world?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The understanding of the world millennia ago was very different from what we have today. Many peoples, for example, believed that the Earth was flat, a conception that has been debunked for centuries and is now widely illustrated by images from space (Hu, X., Shum, C.K. & Bevis, M, ; , Earth 3D Model. NASA ; Hossenfelder, Sabine, ). Thus, when reporting events, ancient peoples considered the "world" as the nearby horizon they knew. With this idea, they could not have been referring to global scales as we understand them today.
